original_title: Sri Lanka sees pick up in foreign investment after IMF loan approval, but shares remain low & muted
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s shares edged down to close at over  one week low on Friday dragged down by transportation and capital goods sectors, while investors continues adopt a wait and see approach until clear direction being given on local debt restructuring, an analyst said.
“The local investing sentiment drops down but a pick up is noted in foreign investment as the International Monetary Fund loan approval is granted” an analyst said.
The main All Share Price Index (ASPI) was down 0.20 percent or 18.78 points to 9,260.41, while the most liquid index S&P SL20 was down 0.06 percent or 1.58 points to 2,716.64.
“The market is low and muted as the banking sector accounts for a large amount of the stock market and is directly compliant to domestic debt restructuring,” an analyst said.

A foreign inflow of 311 million was recorded being the highest net foreign inflow since March 17, while there was a net foreign inflow of 228 million rupees, bringing the total net foreign outflow for the year so far to 3.3 billion rupees.
Out of the total net foreign inflows, a massive chunk of the inflows was generated from Hemas, as investors see potential in the market as the IMF approval succeeds, the analyst said.
“Investors are waiting for clear direction after the IMF comments regarding the local debt restructuring,” an analyst said.
“The debt restructuring fear has caused the banking sector shares to go down, which is dragging the market for the last few days.”
The market generated a turnover of 933 million rupees, below the daily average of 1.7 billion rupees.

“The market is stagnant and there is no buying and selling and turnover has not been moving over a billion because the banking sector is dragging the index down, because of adverse macroeconomic happenings,” an analyst said.

Sri Lanka’s Governor, Nandalal Weerasinghe, stated that the country would not restructure Treasury bills outside of central bank holdings and would engage with major T-bond holders for voluntary ‘optimization.’
Meanwhile, the IMF deal is scheduled to be presented to Parliament on April 25th.
Top losers during market close was Expolanka, Hayleys and Lanka IOC. (Colombo/April21/2023)
